commands.description: run heroku app locally
commands.help:
Start the application specified by a Procfile (defaults to ./Procfile)

Examples:

  heroku local
  heroku local web
  heroku local -f Procfile.test -e .env.test

commands.description: run a one-off command
commands.help:
Example:

  heroku local:run bin/migrate

commands.description: display node-foreman version
commands.help: Display node-foreman version

topics.name: run
topics.description: run a one-off process inside a Heroku dyno

commands.description: run a one-off process inside a heroku dyno
commands.help:
Examples:

  $ heroku run bash
  Running bash on app.... up, run.1
  ~ $

  $ heroku run -s hobby -- myscript.sh -a arg1 -s arg2
  Running myscript.sh -a arg1 -s arg2 on app.... up, run.1

commands.description: run a one-off process inside an existing heroku dyno
commands.help:
Examples:

  $ heroku run:inside web.1 bash
  Running bash on web.1.... up
  ~ $

commands.description: run a detached dyno, where output is sent to your logs
commands.help:
Example:

  $ heroku run:detached ls
  Running ls on app [detached]... up, run.1
  Run heroku logs -a app -p run.1 to view the output.

flags.name: env

commands.description: list trusted IP ranges for a space
commands.help:
Trusted IP ranges are only available on Private Spaces.

The space name is a required parameter. Newly created spaces will have 0.0.0.0/0 set by default
allowing all traffic to applications in the space. More than one CIDR block can be provided at
a time to the commands listed below. For example 1.2.3.4/20 and 5.6.7.8/20 can be added with:

flags.name: space
flags.description: space to get inbound rules from

commands.description: Add one range to the list of trusted IP ranges
commands.help:
Uses CIDR notation.

Example:
  $ heroku trusted-ips:add --space my-space 192.168.2.0/24
  Added 192.168.0.1/24 to trusted IP ranges on my-space

flags.name: confirm
flags.description: set to space name to bypass confirm prompt

commands.description: Remove a range from the list of trusted IP ranges
commands.help:
Uses CIDR notation.

Example:
  $ heroku trusted-ips:remove --space my-space 192.168.2.0/24
  Removed 192.168.2.0/24 from trusted IP ranges on my-space

flags.name: confirm
flags.description: set to space name to bypass confirm prompt

commands.description: list Outbound Rules for a space
commands.help:
Outbound Rules are only available on Private Spaces.

Newly created spaces will have an "Allow All" rule set by default
allowing all egress dyno traffic outside of the space.  You can
remove this default rule to completely stop your private dynos from
talking to the world.

You can add specific rules that only allow your dyno to communicate with trusted hosts.

flags.name: space
flags.description: space to get outbound rules from

commands.description: Add outbound rules to a Private Space
commands.help:
The destination flag uses CIDR notation.

Example:
  $ heroku outbound-rules:add --space my-space --dest 192.168.2.0/24 --protocol tcp --port 80
  Added 192.168.0.1/24 to the outbound rules on my-space

Example with port range:
  $ heroku outbound-rules:add --space my-space --dest 192.168.2.0/24 --protocol tcp --port 80-100
  Added 192.168.0.1/24 to the outbound rules on my-space

Example opening up everything
  $ heroku outbound-rules:add --space my-space --dest 0.0.0.0/0 --protocol any --port any
  Added 0.0.0.0/0 to the outbound rules on my-space

ICMP Rules
The ICMP protocol has types, not ports, but the underlying systems treat them as the same. For this reason,
when you want to allow ICMP traffic you will use the --port flag to specify the ICMP types you want to
allow. ICMP types are numbered, 0-255.

flags.name: confirm
flags.description: set to space name to bypass confirm prompt

flags.name: dest
flags.description: target CIDR block dynos are allowed to communicate with

flags.name: protocol
flags.description: the protocol dynos are allowed to use when communicating with hosts in destination CIDR block. Valid protocols are "tcp", "udp", "icmp", "0-255" and "any".

flags.name: port
flags.description: the port dynos are allowed to use when communicating with hosts in destination CIDR block. Accepts a range in `<lowest port>-<highest port>` format. 0 is the minimum. The maximum port allowed is 65535, except for ICMP with a maximum of 255.

commands.description: Remove a Rules from the list of Outbound Rules
commands.help:
Example:
  $ heroku outbound-rules:remove --space my-space 4
  Removed 192.168.2.0/24 from trusted IP ranges on my-space

flags.name: confirm
flags.description: set to space name to bypass confirm prompt

topic.name: pipelines
topic.description: manage collections of apps in pipelines

commands.description: add this app to a pipeline
commands.help:
The app and pipeline names must be specified.
The stage of the app will be guessed based on its name if not specified.

Example:
  $ heroku pipelines:add example -a example-admin -s production
  Adding example-admin to example pipeline as production... done

flags.name: stage
flags.description: stage of first app in pipeline

commands.description: create a new pipeline
commands.help:
An existing app must be specified as the first app in the pipeline.
The pipeline name will be inferred from the app name if not specified.
The stage of the app will be guessed based on its name if not specified.

Example:
  $ heroku pipelines:create -a example-staging
  ? Pipeline name: example
  ? Stage of example-staging: staging
  Creating example pipeline... done
  Adding example-staging to example pipeline as staging... done

flags.name: stage
flags.description: stage of first app in pipeline

commands.description: destroy a pipeline
commands.help:
Example:
  $ heroku pipelines:destroy example
  Destroying example pipeline... done

commands.description: promote the latest release of this app to its downstream app(s)

Example:

  Promoting example-staging to example (production)... done, v23
  Promoting example-staging to example-admin (production)... done, v54

Example:
  $ heroku pipelines:promote -a example-staging --to my-production-app1,my-production-app2
  Starting promotion to apps: my-production-app1,my-production-app2... done
  Waiting for promotion to complete... done
  Promotion successful
  my-production-app1: succeeded
  my-production-app2: succeeded

flags.name: to
flags.description: comma separated list of apps to promote to

commands.description: create a new app
commands.help:
Examples:

 $ heroku apps:create
 Creating app... done, stack is cedar-14
 https://floating-dragon-42.heroku.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/floating-dragon-42.git

 # or just
 $ heroku create

 # specify a buildpack
 $ heroku apps:create --buildpack https://github.com/some/buildpack.git

 # specify a name
 $ heroku apps:create example

 # create a staging app
 $ heroku apps:create example-staging --remote staging

 # create an app in the eu region
 $ heroku apps:create --region eu

flags.description: specify region for the app to run in

if DYNO is not specified, restarts all dynos on app

  Restarting web dynos... done

  $ heroku ps:restart
  Restarting dynos... done

  $ heroku ps:restart
  Restarting dynos... done

commands.description: scale dyno quantity up or down
commands.help:
Appending a size (eg. web=2:Standard-2X) allows simultaneous scaling and resizing.

Omitting any arguments will display the app's current dyno formation, in a
format suitable for passing back into ps:scale.

Examples:

  $ heroku ps:scale web=3:Standard-2X worker+1
  Scaling dynos... done, now running web at 3:Standard-2X, worker at 1:Standard-1X.

  $ heroku ps:scale
  web=3:Standard-2X worker=1:Standard-1X

commands.description: scale dyno quantity up or down
commands.help:
Appending a size (eg. web=2:Standard-2X) allows simultaneous scaling and resizing.

Omitting any arguments will display the app's current dyno formation, in a
format suitable for passing back into ps:scale.

Examples:

  $ heroku ps:scale web=3:Standard-2X worker+1
  Scaling dynos... done, now running web at 3:Standard-2X, worker at 1:Standard-1X.

  $ heroku ps:scale
  web=3:Standard-2X worker=1:Standard-1X

  $ heroku ps:scale
  web=3:Standard-2X worker=1:Standard-1X

commands.description: manage dyno sizes
commands.help:
Called with no arguments shows the current dyno size.

Called with one argument sets the size.
Where SIZE is one of free|hobby|standard-1x|standard-2x|performance

Called with 1..n TYPE=SIZE arguments sets the quantity per type.

commands.description: list available regions for deployment
display the releases for an app
commands.help:
Example:

 $ heroku releases
 === example Releases
 v1 Config add FOO_BAR email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)
 v2 Config add BAR_BAZ email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)
 v3 Config add BAZ_QUX email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)

commands.description: view detailed information for a release
rollback to a previous release
commands.help: If RELEASE is not specified, it will rollback one release

commands.description: lists your add-ons and attachments
commands.help:
The default filter applied depends on whether you are in a Heroku app
directory. If so, the --app flag is implied. If not, the default of --all
is implied. Explicitly providing either flag overrides the default
behavior.

Examples:

  $ heroku addons --all
  $ heroku addons --app acme-inc-www

Overview of Add-ons:

  Add-ons are created with the `addons:create` command, providing a reference
  to an add-on service (such as `heroku-postgresql`) or a service and plan
  (such as `heroku-postgresql:hobby-dev`).

  At creation, each add-on is given a globally unique name. In addition, each
  add-on has at least one attachment alias to each application which uses the
  add-on. In all cases, the owning application will be attached to the add-on.
  An attachment alias is unique to its application, and is used as a prefix to
  any environment variables it exports to the application.

  In this example, a `heroku-postgresql` add-on is created and its given name
  is `postgresql-deep-6913` with a default attachment alias of `DATABASE`:

    $ heroku addons:create heroku-postgresql --app my-app
    Creating postgresql-deep-6913... done, (free)
    Adding postgresql-deep-6913 to my-app... done
    Setting DATABASE_URL and restarting my-app... done, v5
    Database has been created and is available

    $ heroku addons --app my-app
    Add-on                                     Plan       Price
    ─────────────────────────────────────────  ─────────  ─────
    heroku-postgresql (postgresql-deep-6913)   hobby-dev  free
    └─ as DATABASE

  The add-on name and, in some cases, the attachment alias can be specified by
  the user. For instance, we can add a second database to the app, specifying
  both these identifiers:

    $ heroku addons:create heroku-postgresql --app my-app --name main-db --as PRIMARY_DB
    Creating main-db... done, (free)
    Adding main-db to my-app... done
    Setting PRIMARY_DB_URL and restarting my-app... done, v6
    Database has been created and is available

    $ heroku addons --app my-app
    Add-on                                     Plan       Price
    ─────────────────────────────────────────  ─────────  ─────
    heroku-postgresql (main-db)                hobby-dev  free
    └─ as PRIMARY_DB

    heroku-postgresql (postgresql-deep-6913)   hobby-dev  free
    └─ as DATABASE

  Attachment aliases can also be specified when making attachments:

    $ heroku addons:attach main-db --app my-app --as ANOTHER_NAME
    Attaching main-db as ANOTHER_NAME to my-app... done
    Setting ANOTHER_NAME vars and restarting my-app... done, v7

    $ heroku addons --app my-app
    Add-on                                     Plan       Price
    ─────────────────────────────────────────  ─────────  ─────
    heroku-postgresql (main-db)                hobby-dev  free
    ├─ as PRIMARY_DB
    └─ as ANOTHER_NAME

    heroku-postgresql (postgresql-deep-6913)   hobby-dev  free
    └─ as DATABASE

  For more information, read https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/add-ons.

flags.name: all
flags.description: show add-ons and attachments for all accessible apps

commands.description: attach add-on resource to a new app

open an add-on's Dev Center documentation in your browser

open an add-on's dashboard in your browser

flags.name: show-url
flags.description: show URL, do not open browser

commands.description: list all available plans for an add-on services
Rename an add-on.
list all available add-on services
change add-on plan
commands.help:
See available plans with `heroku addons:plans SERVICE`.

Note that `heroku addons:upgrade` and `heroku addons:downgrade` are the same.
Either one can be used to change an add-on plan up or down.

https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/managing-add-ons

Examples:

  Upgrade an add-on by service name:

  $ heroku addons:upgrade heroku-redis:premium-2

  Upgrade a specific add-on:

  $ heroku addons:upgrade swimming-briskly-123 heroku-redis:premium-2

commands.description: change add-on plan
commands.help:
See available plans with `heroku addons:plans SERVICE`.

Note that `heroku addons:upgrade` and `heroku addons:downgrade` are the same.
Either one can be used to change an add-on plan up or down.

https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/managing-add-ons

Examples:

  Upgrade an add-on by service name:

  $ heroku addons:upgrade heroku-redis:premium-2

  Upgrade a specific add-on:

  $ heroku addons:upgrade swimming-briskly-123 heroku-redis:premium-2

commands.description: fork an existing app into a new one
commands.help:
Copy config vars and Heroku Postgres data, and re-provision add-ons to a new app.
New app name should not be an existing app. The new app will be created as part of the forking process.

Example:

  $ heroku fork --from my-production-app --to my-development-app

commands.description: fork an existing app into a new one
commands.help:
Copy config vars and Heroku Postgres data, and re-provision add-ons to a new app.
New app name should not be an existing app. The new app will be created as part of the forking process.

Example:

  $ heroku fork --from my-production-app --to my-development-app

commands.description: opens a redis prompt
gets information about redis
wait for Redis instance to be available
display credentials information
sets DATABASE as your REDIS_URL
set the number of seconds to wait before killing idle connections
commands.help: Sets the number of seconds to wait before killing idle connections. A value of zero means that connections will not be closed.

commands.description: set the key eviction policy
commands.help:
Set the key eviction policy when instance reaches its storage limit. Available policies for key eviction include:

    noeviction      # returns errors when memory limit is reached
    allkeys-lru     # removes less recently used keys first
    volatile-lru    # removes less recently used keys first that have an expiry set
    allkeys-random  # evicts random keys
    volatile-random # evicts random keys but only those that have an expiry set
    volatile-ttl    # only evicts keys with an expiry set and a short TTL

commands.description: manage maintenance windows
commands.help: Set or change the maintenance window for your Redis instance

flags.name: force
flags.description: start maintenance without entering application maintenance mode

flags.name: wait-interval
flags.description: how frequently to poll in seconds (to avoid rate limiting)
